awd_titl_txt: RUI: Characterizing the Role of Regulatory Genes in Adaptive Evolution to Complex Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
This work will characterize a fundamental mechanism of evolution, not only leading to a better understanding of the evolutionary process, but eventually allowing for prediction of evolutionary outcomes. The investigators will use experimental evolution, a technique where organisms are evolved in the laboratory under strict conditions, allowing the PI to probe basic questions about the evolutionary process. This process will allow the PI to understand the role of advantageous mutations, including in genes that affect expression of other genes. These types of mutations may be particularly advantageous for organisms in changing environments. This work will be performed in collaboration with undergraduate and master's students at a Hispanic and Minority Serving Institution (HSI and MSI), where almost 90% of students are from groups underrepresented in STEM fields. Further, the PI will integrate this project into her upper division microbiology course as an authentic research experience for 24-48 undergraduate students per year, and perform outreach activities related to this project with K-12 educators. In these ways, the research will help to increase the diversity of students entering the STEM pipeline and leave them better prepared for roles in STEM fields.

Changes in gene regulation are a driving force for evolution. Cis regulatory elements are often the cause of evolutionary change when comparing different species, whereas trans regulatory elements are often altered when organisms need to adapt to changing environments. Experimental evolution studies with microbes have begun to probe the role of these factors, but often in unchanging environments where either functional or cis regulatory changes would be favored. The PI will explore the role mutations in trans regulatory elements play in adaptation to a heterogeneous environment by focusing on mutations identified in two regulatory genes, cytR and sspA, that they have shown are adaptive in long-term cultures of Escherichia coli in complex media. To characterize their role in adaptation, the PI will first correlate the adaptive genotype with the transcriptome of the population to identify gene expression changes, and determine which of those changes confer the adaptive phenotype. The PI will then perform experimental evolution on mutant cells to determine how these mutations may change the evolutionary pathways cells can use to adapt to a heterogeneous environment. Understanding how these types of regulatory changes affect adaptation will contribute to the fundamental understanding of evolutionary principles.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding the fundamental mechanisms underlying evolution is essential to understanding biology, as all biological organisms are the product of evolution. In order to probe these processes, we can perform “experimental evolution” in the lab, which allows scientists to observe evolution in real-time. Bacteria are an excellent model organism for experimental evolution, as they can replicate to large population numbers quickly. Our research group uses a species of bacteria, Escherichia coli, because it can grow in many different environments, and much is already known about the function of different genes in the E. coli genome. We can study evolution in this organism by growing bacterial populations in a stressful environment, in our case long-term cultures where nutrient availability is low and other stresses, like non-neutral pH and oxygen availability, are high. We can then look at how the cells respond by determining what mutations in their genome give them the ability to survive in this environment and characterizing how those mutations give an advantage to the cells. 

We first focused on a gene in E. coli named sspA (stringent starvation protein A) because we frequently observed mutations in this gene during incubation in long-term cultures. We determined that mutations in this gene give cells an advantage in lon-term cultures, and that different mutations have different outcomes as to how much of an advantage they confer. We further characterized this gene in two ways: first, we determined how mutations in this gene affect the expression of other genes in the cell. We knew from previously published work that this gene has regulatory functions. We determined that multiple genes are affected by mutations in this gene, and each type of mutation had a distinct set of effects. The second way we characterized this gene is by growing mutant cells in another long-term culture and determining the new mutations that arose. We identified novel mutations that occur only when sspA is mutated first, indicating that having this mutation changes the pathways that cells can use when evolving in stressful conditions.     

Second, we characterized genes that have altered expression in long-term cultures. We identified a specific set of genes which are only expressed in long-term cultures, and determined that some of them are required for survival in this environment. We also observed that genes involved in cell movement are turned on more highly in long-term cultures, even though this activity is not required for survival. Lastly, we have identified other genes that are needed for survival in long-term cultures, and we have begun to characterize these genes as well. Overall, this work provides more understanding of the mechanisms that allow bacterial cells to survive and adapt to stressful and changing conditions.

This work was completed by the PI as well as 12 students (two Master’s students, one post-baccalaureate student, and nine undergraduate students) at a comprehensive state university where ~90% of the students are from at least one group minoritzed in science. All 12 of the students are the first in their families to complete a college degree, and all 12 identify as Latinx or Afro-Latinx. Five of these students are currently pursing graduate degrees (four are in Ph.D. programs and one in a Master’s in Biology program), three completed Master’s degrees are now in STEM-focused jobs, and the rest of the students are currently in jobs in STEM-fields. This project was integrated into an upper division microbiology course as an authentic research experience for over 220 undergraduate students which increased the students’ interest in and understanding of bacterial evolution. In these ways, this project helped to increase the diversity of students entering the STEM pipeline and helped them become better prepared for roles in STEM fields.
